On Feb. 19, 1942, the American Government decided to imprison Japanese Americans. At this time, the Chinese Exclusion Act was in place as well. And so this racism spread to more than just Japanese Americans: it spread to Chinese and Korean Americans too and lasted beyond WW2. This isn't the first or last time Asians have been targeted either. From modern coronavirus racism to the Chinese Exclusion Act to Japanese internment, they are often the butt of small eyes and accent jokes. And arguably the worst part? It's normalized and the racism is ignored. It is often argued that Asian Americans are not real people of color, because of wage gap statistics and the model minority myth. It's true-Asians often make higher salaries than other races, even white people. But what isn't talked about, is that the Asian community has the largest wealth gap and much of the salaries/wealth from richer Asian Americans comes from the East. As a result, they rarely receive funding. So those "positive stereotypes" like being good at math, hardworking, etc creates discrimination in school admissions, workplace hiring, etc. Affirmative action doesn't help this community. And this is when the model minority myth becomes harmful. So on this day of remembrance, it's important to remember to include Asian Americans in the fight for equality and as your next US Senator, I will ensure that no community is left behind. "Forty-one years ago, we were blessed to birth and deliver Stephany Rose to this life. From the beginning, we knew she was spirited and special. She always had a thirst for knowledge. Before she could even read, we‚Äôd find her in a corner attempting to study the Bible‚Äîupside down nonetheless. She wrote her first book in first grade; spent hours reading when her siblings were out playing; and was always the first one up, dressed and ready for school‚Äîeven when we may have been hitting the snooze button for a little extra sleep. Stephany‚Äôs love for learning and spirit carried on into adulthood as she was the first in our family to earn a Ph.D. But having knowledge was never enough for her. Always at the heart of her growth was to use what she learned to challenge situations she perceived as problematic and unjust. When she was 8 or 9 years old she demanded to play a season of little league baseball, not because she was super athletic (she was not); but, because as a girl she felt she should have the same options as her brothers. Imagine being a parent to that! While it may not have always been easy, nurturing her sense of fairness has helped us as a family and community to see things differently. As we celebrate her years in this life, we can look back and see how the different parts of her character have shaped her for this journey of running for the US Senate. Her thirst for and use of knowledge to help make the world fair and just for those who have been overlooked far too long has always been with her. We are honored to run with her because we know her commitment to serving people is shaped in who she is called to be. We hope that you and the people of Colorado will come to see it as well. Please join us in celebrating our daughter as she continues in her journey this side of life. Whether you are able to volunteer, donate and/or vote for her, your support would be a tremendous blessing. We know the gift she has been to us and we know the kind of leader she will be for the people of Colorado."
